clusters.title: Homeschooling Growth
clusters.description: The cluster highlights significant growth in homeschooling in the U.S. and the UK, with a 38% increase in homeschooled children in the UK from 2017 to 2020 and over 75,000 children homeschooled in the UK by 2019/2020. In the U.S., homeschooling numbers rose from 850,000 in 1999 to over 2.5 million in 2020, reaching almost 4 million students in recent years. The homeschooling rate increased from 3.4% in 2019 to over 11% in 2021. Taxpayers save over $56 billion annually due to homeschooling, reflecting its economic impact. The data also shows variation in homeschooling rates across different demographics and parental labor force participation.

clusters.title: Education Challenges
clusters.description: The data highlights preferences and challenges associated with homeschooling versus classroom-based education. A significant majority of students (83.5%), parents (95.6%), and teachers (83.8%) prefer classroom-based schooling. During the national lockdown, 87% of households resorted to homeschooling, with many parents finding it challenging (59%), stressful (49%), and exhausting (40%). Despite the difficulties, 76% found homeschooling acceptable. Concerns include children's reading struggles, screen time, and limited outdoor activities, with 95% of parents worried about their children's eyesight. Additionally, 52.9% of teachers worry about the negative impact of homeschooling on academic performance.

related_facts.fact_group_content: The average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually.
The average score for homeschooled students was 1093.1.
Homeschooled students scored 80.5 points higher than the public school average.
Homeschooled students scored 37.5 points higher than the private religious school average.
Homeschooled students scored 30.7 points lower than the private independent school average.
Homeschooled students scored 38.6 points better than predicted after correcting for background factors.
The average for homeschooling students is generally between 22 and 23 points, while the average for all students is around 21 points.
Homeschool students’ adjusted total score outscored private school students by 3 points.
Homeschool students’ adjusted total score outscored charter school students by 4.5 points.
Homeschool students’ adjusted total score outscored public school students by 12.2 points.
Homeschool students’ adjusted total score outscored the 'not provided' category by 4.5 points.
Homeschool students scored 3 to 12.1 points higher on the adjusted total score than students from other school types.
The median scores of homeschool students were typically in the 70th to 80th percentile.
Homeschool students in grades 1 to 4 perform one grade level above their age-level public/private school peers.
Homeschool students’ writing scores were 1.8 points higher than private school students.
Homeschool students’ writing scores were 2.3 points higher than charter school students.
Homeschool students’ writing scores were 5.4 points higher than public school students.
Homeschool students’ writing scores were 1.6 points higher than the 'not provided' category.
Homeschool students scored 1.6 to 5.4 points higher on the adjusted writing section than students from other school types.
Homeschool students’ adjusted verbal scores were 1.3 points higher than private school students.
Homeschool students’ adjusted verbal scores were 1.8 points higher than charter school students.
Homeschool students’ adjusted verbal scores were 4.5 points higher than public school students.
Homeschool students’ adjusted verbal scores were 1.4 points higher than the 'not provided' category.
Homeschool students scored 1.296 to 4.454 points higher on the adjusted verbal section than students from other school types.
Homeschool students’ quantitative adjusted score was 2.3 points higher than public school students.
Homeschool students’ quantitative adjusted score was 1.4 points higher than the 'not provided' category.
Homeschool students scored 1.436 to 2.310 points higher on the quantitative section than public school students and 'not provided' groups.

In eighth grade math, public school students whose parents are college graduates score at the 63rd percentile, whereas students whose parents have less than a high school diploma score at the 28th percentile.
Students taught at home by mothers who never finished high school score a full 55 percentile points higher than public school students from families of comparable educational backgrounds.

clusters.title: Academic Performance
clusters.description: Homeschooling costs between $700 and $1,800 annually per student. Homeschooled students generally outperform their peers, scoring on average 80.5 points higher than public school students and 37.5 points higher than private religious school students. Their adjusted scores surpass those of students from various school types in verbal, writing, and quantitative sections. Median scores typically fall in the 70th to 80th percentile, with students in grades 1 to 4 performing a grade level above their peers in public or private schools.

related_facts.fact_group_content: 83% of parents of homeschooled children cite concern about the school environment as a reason.
80% of parents cited concern about school environment as a reason for homeschooling.
25% of parents cited concern about school environment as the most important reason for homeschooling.
73 percent of homeschooling parents are dissatisfied with the academic instruction available in local schools.
72% of parents cite dissatisfaction with academic instruction at other schools as a reason.
73% of parents cited dissatisfaction with academic instruction at other schools as a reason for homeschooling.
15% of parents cited dissatisfaction with academic instruction at other schools as the most important reason for homeschooling.
75% of parents cite preference to provide moral instruction as a reason.
75% of parents cited a desire to provide moral instruction as a reason for homeschooling.
72% of parents cite the desire to emphasize family life together as a reason.
75% of parents cited emphasis on family life together as a reason for homeschooling.
53% of parents cite the desire to provide religious instruction as a reason.
13% of parents cited a desire to provide religious instruction as the most important reason for homeschooling.
50% of parents cite the desire to provide a nontraditional approach to education as a reason.
21% of parents cite their child's special needs as a reason for homeschooling.
15% of parents of homeschooling children cite a physical or mental health problem as a reason for homeschooling.
2% of parents cite a temporary illness as a reason for homeschooling.

clusters.description: The primary motivations for homeschooling include dissatisfaction with local school academic instruction (73%), concern about school environment (80%), and a preference for moral instruction (75%). Additionally, parents often emphasize family life (72%) and nontraditional education approaches (50%). Less commonly, homeschooling is driven by children's special needs (21%) or health issues (15%).
